case_data.plaintiff_description: City and county governments and entities affected by funding changes resulting from President Trump's executive orders.
special_collections: Trump Administration 2.0: Challenges to the Government
case_data.summary:
During his first eight months in office, President Donald Trump signed several executive orders that directed government agencies to add new conditions to federal grants, including, Executive Order 14168, which instructed agencies to end funding of “gender ideology” and ensure grants did not promote it,  Executive Order 14173, which directed agencies to ban programs promoting Diversity Equity and Inclusion (DEI) and make compliance “material” under the False Claims Act, and Executive Order 14332 which required discretionary grants to advance the President’s policy priorities and prohibited use of funds for racial preferences, denial of the sex binary, or “anti-American values.” 

On August 20, 2025, several cities and counties in California, as well as the Monroe County Airport Authority in New York, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD); the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and its Secretary; and several other federal agencies and their respective leadership. 

Plaintiffs challenged conditions Defendants imposed on federal grants to coerce compliance with executive policy objectives as outlined in President Trump’s Executive Orders. Plaintiffs alleged that these conditions were unconstitutionally vague and violated Separation of Powers, the Spending Clause, and the Fifth and Tenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution. Plaintiffs also alleged that implementation of conditions imposed by Defendants violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). Plaintiffs requested declarations from the court that grant conditions outlined by Defendants were unlawful, as well as a preliminary and permanent injunction enjoining Defendants from imposing or enforcing the grant conditions or any materially similar terms or conditions.

On August 21, 2025, the case was assigned to Chief United States District Judge Richard Seeborg. That same day, Plaintiffs filed a Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO) asking the court to immediately halt enforcement of grant conditions that required compliance with President Trump’s Executive Orders. On August 27, 2025, Judge Seeborg granted the TRO. First, looking at jurisdictional concerns, standing, and ripeness, the court found the challenged grant conditions constituted “final agency action” under the APA because they imposed an “‘immediate and significant practical burden’ on Plaintiffs.” Judge Seeborg then turned to the merits, finding that Plaintiffs were likely to succeed. In weighing the harms, Judge Seeborg found that Plaintiffs would suffer irreparable harm if the grant conditions were not enjoined because Plaintiffs would be forced to choose between complying with grant conditions that were “likely unconstitutional" or “forgoing key federal grant funding.” The court denied Defendants’ request for a bond, finding that there was “no realistic likelihood of harm” to Defendants by enjoining their conduct. The court additionally held that the public interest was “served” by allowing Plaintiffs clarity in the funding they would be allotted, which would then be used to provide key services to the public. 2025 WL 2469330. 

 On September 8, 2025, Plaintiffs filed an Amended Complaint, naming four additional Plaintiffs, expanding venue to San Francisco and Oakland Division to include the new Plaintiffs and adding additional allegations of fact, as to specific grant programs and projects that were affected by the Executive Orders’ grant conditions. Plaintiffs also filed a Motion for Preliminary Injunction, with their arguments for a preliminary injunction mirroring those accepted by Judge Seeborg when he granted Plaintiffs’ TRO. The court granted the preliminary injunction on September 23, 2025. The court found that the agencies’ actions in imposing grant conditions were arbitrary and capricious and “in excess of statutory authority,” in violation of the APA. The grant conditions were also “contrary to the constitution” because they violated due process and separation of power. Thus, Plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their claim. The court also weighed the harms as it did when it granted Plaintiffs’ TRO, and again found that Plaintiffs stood to face irreparable harm. 2025 WL 2721390.

This case remains ongoing. While TROs are not appealable, preliminary injunctions are. It is possible that the administration will appeal, though this had not happened as of October 1.
case_data.summary_short:
In his first eight months as president, Donald Trump signed several orders that changed the rules for getting money from the federal government. One order blocked funding for anything related to “gender ideology.” Another order stopped support for Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) programs, and said groups could face serious consequences if they broke these rules. A third order said that grants had to match the president’s priorities. This order also banned giving money based on racial preferences, denying the idea that there are only two sexes, or promoting “anti-American values.”
On August 20, 2025, some cities and counties in California, along with an airport group in New York State, sued the government. They filed their case in a federal court in California. They said the new grant rules were unfair, too confusing, possibly unconstitutional, and didn’t follow the proper steps when making new rules. They asked the court to stop the government from using these rules.

The case went to Chief Judge Richard Seeborg. On August 27, the judge said the government had to stop using the new rules for now. He said the rules hurt the cities and counties, probably violated the law, and could cause serious problems if they continued. He also said the public should know exactly what the funding rules are.

On September 8, the plaintiffs (the cities, counties, and airport group) added more people and more examples to their lawsuit. They also asked the judge to keep blocking the new rules for a longer time. On September 23, the judge agreed with them again and said the government agencies went too far, did not follow the law, and possibly violated the Constitution.

The case is still ongoing.

1  I.  INTRODUCTION 
2  Plaintiffs bring this action reluctantly, only after the current Administration’s actions have left 
3  them no other means of protecting the federal funding essential to their communities.  For years, 
4  Plaintiffs have relied on congressionally authorized grant programs to deliver core public services that 
5  safeguard public safety and health, connect residents to opportunity, and sustain local economies.  They 
6  have endeavored to work cooperatively with federal agencies to administer these programs, but the 
7  lawful and predictable administration of these grants has now been upended. 
8  The Constitution vests Congress—not the Executive—with the authority to make laws and 
9  appropriate federal funds.  See U.S. Const. art. I, § 8; Cunningham v. Neagle, 135 U.S. 1, 83–84 (1890).  
10  While the Executive Branch is charged with faithfully executing the laws enacted by Congress, that duty 
11  does not include the power to unilaterally rewrite or expand the statutory terms under which federal 
12  funds are awarded.  City of Los Angeles v. Barr, 941 F.3d 931, 945 (9th Cir. 2019); City & Cnty. of San
